thread.title: It's decision time in county exec race
thread.title_full: It's decision time in county exec race

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: It's decision time in county exec race
text:
Unless you're rabidly loyal to a political party, deciding which candidate deserves your vote often can be a difficult process of parsing what sets one politician apart from another. We're here to help.
To assist voters in making an educated decision in the race for Monroe County executive on Election Day — Tuesday, Nov. 3 — the Democrat and Chronicle has set out to contrast the three candidates.
It's not always easy. While the Green Party candidate's positions often stand apart, the Democrat and the Republican in the race agree on some major issues, much as they might be loathe to admit it.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Rajesh Barnabas challenges status quo
Both Sandra Frankel and Cheryl Dinolfo have vowed not to raise property taxes (or service fees, or chargebacks, or whatever other creatively named expenses might appear on property owners' tax bills).
They also have pledged to set up a county Office of Public Integrity. Both women say they will be active participants in an ongoing effort to address the region's deep-seated poverty.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Dinolfo say she'll be a problem solver
But even in these areas, they differ on the details. And on other topics, they are miles apart.
Dinolfo and Frankel come from very different backgrounds in public office. They offer distinct approaches to stabilizing the county's finances, providing child care subsidies to working families and shepherding business development.
If Green Party candidate Rajesh Barnabas seems to offer a more stark contrast to his opponents, that's by design. He says he's in the race to raise new and different ideas, and indeed, you won't find another candidate proposing a voter referendum on creating a county-wide public school system.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Frankel vows to 'clean up county'
Bottom line: The old cliche that all politicians are the same is demonstrably untrue in this race.
Yet by many measures, this has been a quiet election year. The county executive candidates spent about $114,000 combined on the race between July and September. Back in the 2011 county executive race, the Republican candidate alone spent more than twice as much money during the same three-month period.
Comparatively sleepy though the race may be, the outcome is important.
For the first time in 12 years, the county executive seat is up for grabs with no incumbent in the race. Republican County Executive Maggie Brooks is term-limited and could not run for re-election.
Whoever wins, someone new will occupy the county executive's office in January. That means a new leader setting priorities in the county's massive $1 billion budget, managing social programs that have become political hot potatoes in recent years and appointing department heads who oversee public health and safety, parks, sewage and other services that affect county residents on a daily basis.
Whomever you choose, make an informed decision.
DRILEY@Gannett.com
The job
What it entails: Acting as the chief executive officer and administrative head of county government.
Term: Four years.
Salary: $120,000.
Term limit: No more than three consecutive terms.
Responsibilities: Prepares the annual county budget, which totals about $1 billion this year.
Oversees county spending and the collection of taxes and other revenue.
Supervises county agencies, departments and properties; appoints department heads.
Carries out and enforces actions of the County Legislature.
Negotiates and executes contracts on the county’s behalf, as authorized by the legislature.
Perk: Has the power to veto county legislation.
Drawback: Is required to show up to every County Legislature meeting.
Voice of the Voter
Democrat Sandra Frankel, Republican Cheryl Dinolfo and Green Party candidate Rajesh Barnabas will participate Monday in a Monroe County executive debate hosted by Voice of the Voter.
The debate is from 8 to 9 p.m. and will air live on AM 1370 and WXXI-TV, and will stream on DemocratandChronicle.com , WXXI.org/news , 13wham.com and wdkx.com . An extended portion of the debate will be streamed online from 9 to 9:15 p.m.
The debate will be moderated by WXXI Connections ’ host Evan Dawson. The candidates will share their platforms and answer questions from panelists Sheila Rayam, a community engagement editor for the Democrat and Chronicle ; Sean Carroll, executive producer, 13WHAM-TV; and Tariq Spence, morning host, WDKX 103.9.
The debate is part of Voice of the Voter, a collaboration among WXXI Public Broadcasting, the Democrat and Chronicle , 13WHAM-TV and WDKX 103.9, which is committed to bringing citizens’ concerns to the forefront in political issues.
VoteUp debate watch party
Watch the 2015 Voice of the Voter Monroe County executive debate on the big screen Monday with Democrat and Chronicle civic engagement reporter David Riley.
David covers government and politics from City Hall to the County Office Building. He also focuses on how citizens and voters shape public affairs, as well as the obstacles that sometimes prevent their voices from being heard.
Buy Photo David Riley (Photo: File photo)
At the watch party, visitors will help try to sort out the facts, play Debate Bingo and cast votes for the best election-themed cocktails at The Daily Refresher.
Doors will open at 7 p.m. and the one-hour debate gets under way at 8 p.m. The Daily Refresher is at 293 Alexander St. You must be 21 years or older. Free admission, cash bar.
